name: First-Year Seminar: You Don't Have to Be a Rocket Scientist
desc: The goal of this seminar is to develop tools for extracting information from or finding flaws in news reports and popular science writing. Group work on such issues as biomass fuels, the hydrogen economy, and other alternative energy sources will develop an understanding of their economic and environmental impact.

name: First-Year Seminar: Foundations of Chemistry: A Historical and Modern Perspective
desc: Students will learn about ways in which scientists think. They will explore how new knowledge is generated and examine the impact of science on society. Topics to be considered include the nature of gases, atomic structure and radioactivity, and molecules and the development of new materials.

name: First-Year Seminar: From Imagination to Reality: Idea Entrepreneurism in Science, Business, the Arts
desc: Bringing ideas to fruition is a multistep process. In the present knowledge economy, high value is placed on individuals who both formulate new concepts and bring them to reality. This process requires a number of important skills that will be explored in this course.

name: First-Year Seminar: From Atomic Bombs to Cancer Treatments:  The Broad Scope of Nuclear Chemistry
desc: A course engaging the topic of nuclear chemistry on the introductory chemistry course level (e.g., CHEM 101/102). Atomic structure, nuclear fission, and nuclear fusion processes will be introduced to provide the background necessary to understand applications of the processes. Applications discussed will include power generation, medical treatments, weapons, and more.

name: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics
desc: Special topics course. Content will vary each semester.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Foundations of Chemistry
desc: This course is an introduction to fundamental threshold concepts in chemistry as preparation for the two-course sequence of General Descriptive Chemistry (CHEM 101 and 102). This course emphasizes developing contextualized algebra skills for solving chemistry problems including physical unit conversions, molar mass, and reaction stoichiometry. Permission of instructor required.

name: General Descriptive Chemistry I
desc: The first course in a two-semester sequence. See also CHEM 102. Atomic and molecular structure, stoichiometry and conservation of mass, thermochemical changes and conservation of energy.

name: Quantitative Chemistry Laboratory I
desc: Computerized data collection, scientific measurement, sensors, thermochemistry, spectroscopy, and conductometric titration. Laptop computer required. One four-hour laboratory a week.

name: General Descriptive Chemistry II
desc: The course is the second in a two-semester sequence. See also CHEM 101. Gases, intermolecular forces, solutions, reaction rates, chemical equilibria including acid-base chemistry, thermochemistry, electrochemistry. Honors version available
Prereqs: Prerequisites, CHEM 101 and 101L; C- or better required in CHEM 101.

name: Quantitative Chemistry Laboratory II
desc: Computerized data collection, gas laws, intermolecular forces, redox reactions, chemical kinetics, and acid-base titrations. Laptop computer required. One four-hour laboratory a week.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, CHEM 101L; pre- or corequisite, CHEM 102 or 102H.

name: Special Topics in Chemistry
desc: An undergraduate seminar course that is designated to be a participatory intellectual adventure on an advanced, emergent, and stimulating topic within a selected discipline in chemistry. This course does not count as credit towards the chemistry major.

name: Extraordinary Chemistry of Ordinary Things
desc: Coregistration in CHEM 200 and 101L fulfills the physical and life science with a laboratory requirement (PX). This course helps students understand the chemistry behind important societal issues and the consequences of actions aimed at addressing the issues. Students who have taken CHEM 200 cannot take CHEM 101 for credit.

name: Service Learning in Chemistry
desc: This is an APPLES service-learning course that collaborates with a community partner. Students will develop research questions and test their hypotheses using chemistry lab techniques and instrumentation. Students will keep a reflection journal on their service work and a lab notebook for recording all experimentation. At the end of the semester, students will write a paper and present research posters. Findings will be shared with the community partner. Students must send applications to the instructor.
GenEd: EE- Service Learning, EE- Mentored Research.

name: Modern Analytical Methods for Separation and Characterization
desc: Analytical separations, chromatographic methods, spectrophotometry, acid-base equilibria and titrations, fundamentals of electrochemistry. Honors version available
Prereqs: Prerequisite, CHEM 102 or 102H; C- or better required.

name: Laboratory in Separations and Analytical Characterization of Organic and Biological Compounds
desc: Applications of separation and spectrophotometric techniques to organic compounds, including some of biological interest. One three-hour laboratory a week. Students may not receive credit for both CHEM 241L and CHEM 245L.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, CHEM 102L; pre- or corequisite, CHEM 241 or 241H.

name: Honors Laboratory in Separations and Analytical Characterization of Organic and Biological Compound
desc: Applications of separation and spectrophotometric techniques to samples from the real world, including some of biological interest. Final portion of course consists of group research projects presented to the Department of Chemistry in poster session format. Honors equivalent of CHEM 241L. Students may not receive credit for both CHEM 241L and CHEM 245L. One three-hour laboratory each week.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, CHEM 102L; pre- or corequisite, CHEM 241H.

name: Introduction to Inorganic Chemistry
desc: Chemical periodicity, introductory atomic theory and molecular orbital theory, structure and bonding in solids, descriptive nonmetal chemistry, structures and reactions of transition metal complexes, applications of inorganic complexes and materials.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, CHEM 102 or 102H; C- or better required.

name: Introduction to Organic Chemistry I
desc: Molecular structure and its determination by modern physical methods, correlation between structure and reactivity and the theoretical basis for these relationships, classification of reaction types exhibited by organic molecules using as examples molecules of biological importance. Honors version available
Prereqs: Prerequisite, CHEM 102 or 102H; C- or better required.

name: Introduction to Organic Chemistry II
desc: Continuation of CHEM 261, with particular emphasis on the chemical properties of organic molecules of biological importance. Honors version available
Prereqs: Prerequisite, CHEM 261 or 261H; C- or better required.

name: Laboratory in Organic Chemistry
desc: Continuation of CHEM 241L or 245L with particular emphasis on organic chemistry synthesis protocols, separation techniques, and compound characterization using modern spectroscopic instrumentation. This course serves as an organic chemistry laboratory for premedical and predental students. Students may not receive credit for both CHEM 262L and CHEM 263L. One three-hour laboratory each week.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, CHEM 102L, and CHEM 241L or 245L; pre- or corequisite, CHEM 262 or 262H.

name: Honors Laboratory in Organic Chemistry
desc: Continuation of CHEM 245L with particular emphasis on organic chemistry synthesis protocols, separation techniques, and compound characterization using modern spectroscopic instrumentation. An organic chemistry laboratory for premedical and predental students. Honors equivalent of CHEM 262L. Students may not receive credit for both CHEM 262L and CHEM 263L. One three-hour laboratory each week.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, CHEM 102L, and CHEM 241L or 245L; pre- or corequisite, CHEM 262H; permission of the instructor for students lacking CHEM 262H.

name: Special Topics in Chemistry
desc: Elective topics in the field of chemistry. This course has variable content and may be taken multiple times for credit.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Seminar on Academic Mentoring
desc: Experience includes academic mentoring for small groups, preparing review sessions, and facilitating lecture hall activity. Students will explore concepts in pedagogy, leadership, communication, and group dynamics. Does not fulfill chemistry major requirements. GPA above 3.0 required.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, CHEM 102 or 102H, and MATH 231; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 6 total completions.

name: Undergraduate Internship in Chemistry
desc: The sponsored, off-campus work must involve at least 135 hours. Does not fulfill any requirement in the chemistry major or minor. Chemistry majors only. Permission of the department and supervision of chemistry faculty member required.
GenEd: EE- Service Learning, EE- Field Work.

name: Research in Chemistry for Undergraduates
desc: Required preparation, one CHEM course 420 or higher, or permission of the instructor. For advanced chemistry and applied sciences majors conducting on-campus research. Students prepare a report for their faculty supervisor and present their work at a poster session. May count only once as a chemistry elective. Honors version available
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Special Problems in Chemistry
desc: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Literature or laboratory work equivalent of one to three hours each week. Honors version available
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 9 total credits. 3 total completions.

name: Honors Colloquium in Chemistry
desc: Weekly meetings complement research carried out under CHEM 395H. Expands students' exposure to specialized areas of research through guided readings and seminars with invited speakers. Aids students in preparing their research for evaluation. CHEM 395H and 397H together can contribute no more than nine total hours toward graduation.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 2 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: GEN REGISTRATION
desc: GEN REGISTRATION
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics.

name: Instructional Methods in the Chemistry Classroom
desc: Permission of the instructor. This course explores secondary school chemical education through current chemical education theory and classroom teaching. Students will develop a comprehensive approach to teaching chemistry content through student-centered activities.

name: Introduction to Polymers
desc: Chemical structure and nomenclature of macromolecules, synthesis of polymers, characteristic polymer properties.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, CHEM 261 or 261H; pre- or corequisites, CHEM 262 or 262H, and 262L or 263L.

name: Synthesis of Polymers
desc: Synthesis and reactions of polymers; various polymerization techniques.

name: Physical Chemistry of Polymers
desc: Polymerization and characterization of macromolecules in solution.

name: Intermediate Polymer Chemistry
desc: Polymer dynamics, networks and gels.

name: Polymer Materials
desc: Solid-state properties of polymers; polymer melts, glasses and crystals.

name: Introduction to Biological Chemistry
desc: The study of cellular processes including catalysts, metabolism, bioenergetics, and biochemical genetics. The structure and function of biological macromolecules involved in these processes is emphasized. Honors version available

name: Macromolecular Structure and Metabolism
desc: Structure of DNA and methods in biotechnology; DNA replication and repair; RNA structure, synthesis, localization and transcriptional reputation; protein structure/function, biosynthesis, modification, localization, and degradation.

name: Metabolic Chemistry and Cellular Regulatory Networks
desc: Biological membranes, membrane protein structure, transport phenomena; metabolic pathways, reaction themes, regulatory networks; metabolic transformations with carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids, and nucleotides; regulatory networks, signal transduction.

name: Transport in Biological Systems
desc: Permission of the instructor for undergraduates. Diffusion, sedimentation, electrophoresis, flow. Basic principles, theoretical methods, experimental techniques, role in biological function, current topics.

name: Intermediate Analytical Chemistry
desc: Spectroscopy, electroanalytical chemistry, chromatography, thermal methods of analysis, signal processing.

name: Intermediate Analytical Chemistry Laboratory
desc: Experiments in spectroscopy, electroanalytical chemistry, chromatography, thermal methods of analysis, and signal processing. One four-hour laboratory a week and one one-hour lecture.

name: Surface Analysis
desc: This class will focus on analytical techniques capable of probing the physical and chemical properties of surfaces and interfaces. These analyses are extremely challenging, as the sample sizes are small (e.g., 1E14 molecules/cm2 of a material). The course will focus on complementary techniques to assess surface structure and topography, atomic and molecular composition, organization or disorder, and reactivity.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, CHEM 441 or CHEM 481; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Separations
desc: Theory and applications of equilibrium and nonequilibrium separation techniques. Extraction, countercurrent distribution, gas chromatography, column and plane chromatographic techniques, electrophoresis, ultra-centrifugation, and other separation methods.

name: Electroanalytical Chemistry
desc: Basic principles of electrochemical reactions, electroanalytical voltammetry as applied to analysis, the chemistry of heterogeneous electron transfers, and electrochemical instrumentation.

name: Analytical Spectroscopy
desc: Optical spectroscopic techniques for chemical analysis including conventional and laser-based methods. Absorption, fluorescence, scattering and nonlinear spectroscopies, instrumentation and signal processing.

name: Bioanalytical Chemistry
desc: Principles and applications of biospecific binding as a tool for performing selective chemical analysis.

name: Mass Spectrometry
desc: Fundamental theory of gaseous ion chemistry, instrumentation, combination with separation techniques, spectral interpretation for organic compounds, applications to biological and environmental chemistry.

name: Microfabricated Chemical Measurement Systems
desc: Introduction to micro and nanofabrication techniques, fluid and molecular transport at the micrometer to nanometer length scales, applications of microtechnology to chemical and biochemical measurements.

name: Intermediate Inorganic Chemistry
desc: Introduction to symmetry and group theory; bonding, electronic spectra, and reaction mechanisms of coordination complexes; organometallic complexes, reactions, and catalysis; bioinorganic chemistry.

name: Theoretical Inorganic Chemistry
desc: Chemical applications of symmetry and group theory, crystal field theory, molecular orbital theory. The first third of the course, corresponding to one credit hour, covers point symmetry, group theoretical foundations and character tables.

name: Electronic Structure of Transition Metal Complexes
desc: A detailed discussion of ligand field theory and the techniques that rely on the theoretical development of ligand field theory, including electronic spectroscopy, electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy, and magnetism.

name: Organotransition Metal Chemistry
desc: Exploring the synthesis, bonding, and reactivity of of organotransition metal complexes. Topics typically include organometallic ligand classification, the elementary steps of organometallic reactions, and applications in catalysis.

name: Intermediate Organic Chemistry
desc: Modern topics in organic chemistry. Honors version available

name: Bioorganic Chemistry
desc: Bioorganic chemistry integrates topics from synthetic chemistry, biochemistry, and biophysics to study biomacromolecules and develop tools and materials that utilize them.

name: Mechanisms of Organic and Inorganic Reactions
desc: Kinetics and thermodynamics, free energy relationships, isotope effects, acidity and basicity, kinetics and mechanisms of substitution reactions, one- and two-electron transfer processes, principles and applications of photochemistry, organometallic reaction mechanisms.

name: Advanced Organic Chemistry I
desc: A survey of fundamental organic reactions including substitutions, additions, elimination, and rearrangements; static and dynamic stereochemistry; conformational analysis; molecular orbital concepts and orbital symmetry.

name: Advanced Organic Chemistry II
desc: Spectroscopic methods of analysis with emphasis on elucidation of the structure of organic molecules: 1H and 13C NMR, infrared, ultraviolet, ORD-CD, mass, and photoelectron spectroscopy.

name: Synthetic Aspects of Organic Chemistry
desc: Modern synthetic methods and their application to the synthesis of complicated molecules.

name: Organometallics and Catalysis
desc: Structure and reactivity of organometallic complexes and their role in modern catalytic reactions

name: Fundamentals of Materials Science
desc: Crystal geometry, diffusion in solids, mechanical properties of solids, electrical conduction in solids, thermal properties of materials, phase equilibria.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, CHEM 482 or PHYS 128. Pre- or corequisite, PHYS 441.

name: Mathematical Techniques for Chemists
desc: Knowledge of differential and integral calculus. Chemical applications of higher mathematics.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, MATH 383; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Chemistry and Physics of Electronic Materials Processing
desc: Permission of the instructor. A survey of materials processing and characterization used in fabricating microelectronic devices. Crystal growth, thin film deposition and etching, and microlithography.

name: Chemistry and Physics of Surfaces
desc: The structural and energetic nature of surface states and sites, experimental surface measurements, reactions on surfaces including bonding to surfaces and adsorption, interfaces.

name: Introduction to Biophysical Chemistry
desc: Does not carry credit toward graduate work in chemistry or credit toward any track of the B.S. degree with a major in chemistry. Application of thermodynamics to biochemical processes, enzyme kinetics, properties of biopolymers in solution.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, CHEM 261 or 261H, MATH 232, and PHYS 105.

name: Physical Chemistry I
desc: Thermodynamics, kinetic theory, chemical kinetics.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, CHEM 102 or 102H, PHYS 118 or 116; pre- or corequisites, MATH 383 and PHYS 119 or 117; C- or better required in chemistry course prerequisites.

name: Physical Chemistry Laboratory I
desc: Experiments in physical chemistry. One four-hour laboratory each week.

name: Physical Chemistry II
desc: Introduction to quantum mechanics, atomic and molecular structure, spectroscopy, statistical mechanics.

name: Physical Chemistry Laboratory II
desc: Experiments in physical chemistry. Solving thermodynamic and quantum mechanical problems using computer simulations. One three-hour laboratory and a single one-hour lecture each week.

name: Thermodynamics and Introduction to Statistical Thermodynamics
desc: Thermodynamics, followed by an introduction to the classical and quantum statistical mechanics and their application to simple systems. The section on thermodynamics can be taken separately for one hour credit.

name: Chemical Dynamics
desc: Experimental and theoretical aspects of atomic and molecular reaction dynamics.

name: Introduction to Quantum Chemistry
desc: Introduction to the principles of quantum mechanics. Approximation methods, angular momentum, simple atoms and molecules.

name: Introduction to Molecular Spectroscopy
desc: Interaction of radiation with matter; selection rules; rotational, vibrational, and electronic spectra of molecules; laser based spectroscopy and nonlinear optical effects.

name: Quantum Chemistry
desc: Applications of quantum mechanics to chemistry. Molecular structure, time-dependent perturbation theory, interaction of radiation with matter.

name: Statistical Mechanics
desc: Applications of statistical mechanics to chemistry. Ensemble formalism, condensed phases, nonequilibrium processes.

name: Polymer Chemistry Laboratory
desc: Various polymerization techniques and characterization methods. One four-hour laboratory each week.
Prereqs: Pre- or corequisite, CHEM 420 or 421 or 425.

name: Laboratory Techniques for Biochemistry
desc: An introduction to chemical techniques and research procedures of use in the fields of protein and nucleic acid chemistry. Two four-hour laboratories and one one-hour lecture a week.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, BIOL 202; pre- or co-requisite, CHEM 430.

name: Analytical Microscopy
desc: Introduction to microscopy techniques utilized in the analysis of chemical and biological samples with a focus on light, electron, and atomic force microscopy. Permission of instructor required for those missing prerequisites.

name: Synthetic Chemistry Laboratory I
desc: A laboratory devoted to synthesis and characterization of inorganic complexes and materials. A four-hour synthesis laboratory, a characterization laboratory outside of the regular laboratory period, and a one-hour recitation each week.

name: Honors Synthetic Chemistry Lab
desc: This is an honors laboratory course designed to lead you from challenging introductory experiments to five weeks of laboratory work on an independent research project. In addition to exposing you to advanced synthetic techniques, this course will allow you to use multiple modern techniques to characterize the inorganic and organometallic complexes you prepare. Students may not receive credit in both CHEM 551L and CHEM 550L.

name: Synthetic Organic Laboratory
desc: An advanced synthesis laboratory focused on topics in organic chemistry. A four-hour synthesis laboratory, a characterization laboratory outside of the regular laboratory period, and a one-hour recitation each week.

name: Senior Honors Thesis
desc: CHEM 395 must have been in the same laboratory as 692H. Senior majors only. Required of all candidates for honors or highest honors.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, six credit hours of CHEM 395.

name: Introduction to Laboratory Safety
desc: Permission of the instructor for undergraduates. This introductory course in laboratory chemical safety is required for all entering chemistry graduate students. Topics include laboratory emergencies, chemical hazards, laboratory inspections and compliance, working with chemicals, waste handling, case studies of university accidents, laboratory equipment, biosafety, radiation, animals, and microfabrication and nanomaterials.

name: Seminar in Materials Chemistry
desc: Graduate standing required.

name: Chemical Biology
desc: Application of chemical principles and tools to study and manipulate biological systems; in-depth exploration of examples from the contemporary literature. Topics include new designs for the genetic code, drug design, chemical arrays, single molecule experiments, laboratory-based evolution, chemical sensors, and synthetic biology.

name: Seminar in Biological Chemistry
desc: Graduate standing required. Literature survey dealing with topics in protein chemistry and nucleic acid chemistry.

name: Advances in Macromolecular Structure and Function
desc: In-depth analysis of the structure-function relationships governing protein-protein and protein-nucleic acid interactions. Topics include replication, DNA repair, transcription, translation, RNA processing, protein complex assembly, and enzyme regulation. Course includes both the current and classic literature that highlight the techniques used to study these processes.

name: Special Topics in Biological Chemistry
desc: Modern topics in biological chemistry.

name: Literature Seminar in Analytical Chemistry
desc: Graduate standing required. Colloquium of modern analytical chemistry topics presented by graduate students and select invited speakers.

name: Analytical Research Techniques
desc: Introduction to chemical instrumentation including digital and analog electronics, computers, interfacing, and chemometric techniques. Two one-hour lectures a week.

name: Laboratory in Analytical Research Techniques
desc: Experiments in digital and analog instrumentation, computers, interfacing and chemometrics, with applications to chemical instrumentation.

name: Special Topics in Analytical Chemistry
desc: Modern topics in analytical chemistry, including advanced electroanalytical chemistry, advanced mass spectrometry, chemical instrumentation, and other subjects of recent significance. Two lecture hours a week.

name: Analytical Technical Writing Workshop
desc: Students will participate in 12 workshop sessions co-presented by the instructor and TA covering the basics of technical writing. Each workshop is designed to help students prepare successful proposals for external graduate fellowships, but skills practiced are readily extended to the 2nd-year prospectus, manuscript preparation, the thesis, and beyond.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 3 total credits. 1 total completions.

name: Special Topics in Inorganic Chemistry
desc: Permission of the instructor. Research-level survey of topics in inorganic chemistry and related areas.

name: Literature Seminar in Inorganic Chemistry
desc: Graduate standing required.

name: Inorganic Technical Writing Workshop
desc: Students will participate in 11 workshop sessions co-presented by the instructor and TA covering the basics of technical writing. They are designed to help students prepare successful proposals for external graduate fellowships, but skills practiced are readily extended to the 2nd-year prospectus, 3rd-year proposal, manuscript preparation, the thesis, and beyond.

name: Introduction to Chemical Crystallography
desc: The course Introduction to Chemical Crystallography" is intended for graduate students who wish to acquire a basic understanding of crystallography
Prereqs: the mathematical foundations of diffraction principles
GenEd: the hands-on experience in the operation of X-ray diffractometers
Repeat: computer software for crystal structure determination and visualization
Grading: as well as crystallographic databases. The goal of the course is to prepare students to independently operate diffractometers and carry out X-ray structure determinations for their Ph.D. or M.S. theses."
column9: Prerequisites, Knowledge of elementary and differential calculus is assumed; this course is designed to introduce students to the techniques used in solving and refining crystal structures by the use of X-ray diffraction; no prior knowledge of crystallography is required, but students are required to pass the radiation safety exam in the first week of the course.

name: Seminar in Organic Chemistry
desc: Graduate standing required. One afternoon meeting a week and individual consultation with the instructor.

name: Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
desc: Two lecture hours a week.

name: Organic Chemistry
desc: Permission of the instructor. Three to six hours a week.

name: Advanced Materials Science
desc: This course covers the physical fundamentals of material science with an in-depth discussion of structure formation in soft and hard materials and how structure determines material mechanical, electrical, thermal, and optical properties. Topics include amorphous and crystal structures, defects, dislocation theory, thermodynamics and phase diagrams, diffusion, interfaces and microstructures, solidification, and theory of phase transformation. Special emphasis will be on the structure-property relationships of (bio)polymers, (nano)composites, and their structure property relationships.
Grading: Letter gradeSame as: MTSC 780, BMME 780, PHYS 780.

name: Seminar in Physical Chemistry
desc: Graduate standing required. Two hours a week.

name: Special Topics in Physical Chemistry
desc: Permission of the instructor. Modern topics in physical chemistry, chemical physics, or biophysical chemistry. One to three lecture hours a week.

name: Special Topics in Physical Chemistry
desc: Permission of the instructor. Modern topics in physical chemistry, chemical physics, or biophysical chemistry. One to three lecture hours a week.

name: Special Topics in Chemistry
desc: Selected research-level, cross-disciplinary topics in modern chemistry.

name: Research Methodology and Seminar in Polymer/Materials Chemistry
desc: Seminar and directed study on research methods of polymer/materials chemistry. This course provides a foundation for master's thesis or doctoral dissertation research.

name: Research Methodology and Seminar in Biological Chemistry
desc: Seminar and directed study on research methods of biological chemistry. This course provides a foundation for master's thesis or doctoral dissertation research.

name: Research Methodology and Seminar in Analytical Chemistry
desc: Seminar and directed study on research methods of analytical chemistry. The course provides a foundation for master's thesis or doctoral dissertation research.

name: Research Methodology and Seminar in Inorganic Chemistry
desc: Seminar and directed study on research methods of inorganic chemistry. The course provides a foundation for master's thesis or doctoral dissertation research.

name: Research Methodology and Seminar in Organic Chemistry
desc: Seminar and directed study on research methods of organic chemistry. The course provides a foundation for master's thesis or doctoral dissertation research.

name: Research Methodology and Seminar in Physical Chemistry
desc: Seminar and directed study on research methods of physical chemistry. The course provides a foundation for master's thesis or doctoral dissertation research.

name: Master's Research and Thesis
desc: Prerequisite, CHEM 921, 931, 941, 951, 961, or 981.

name: Doctoral Research and Dissertation
desc: Prerequisite, CHEM 921, 931, 941, 951, 961, or 981.
